children.subject:
I can speak on behalf of 2 of the classes (170 and 100). Expect CS 170 to be a very high workload class -- besides the long weekly problem sets and a final project at the end of the semester, it's conceptually difficult to understand for most people. I did very well in CS 70 and 61B and this class is much more challenging as expected from an upper div. DS 100 was a lot easier. If you're good with linear algebra, multivariable calc, and have a basic understanding of statistics (Data 8 level), you shouldn't have trouble completing the weekly labs, homework, and projects. I would say the workload of Data 100 is 61A level but the concepts are more mathematical so they might be easier for you depending on your strengths.

Pairing up CS 170 and DS 100 sounds ok... not too heavy. Not sure how difficult 7B is though and from what I've heard the class's 'easiness' varies between professors. If you're used to taking 3 techs / semester, this should be manageable.

I can speak to Physics 7B. General workload is about the same - Mastering Physics (an online homework system) is the weekly problem set that generally doesn't take too long to complete (~2-3 hours for me per week). If you read the textbook and review/practice additional material, that's probably another 2-3 hours per week. Honestly not a ton of work for a technical class, especially compared to CS 170 which will likely be your heavy hitter for the semester.

I had minimal if any outside-of-class work for the laboratory section. However, I studied hard for the exams as they are very difficult (especially if you have a tough professor).  Basically the material can be difficult and the class is somewhat stressful around exam time, but the week-to-week homework load is not bad at all.

history.content: I'm taking CS170, Physics 7B, and DS 100 and wondering if it this is too heavy in terms of workload and content. I have completed the CS61 series, 70, 188, EE16A/B, and Physics 7A already.
history.subject: CS170, Physics 7B, DS 100 manageable?
